body:
Although I agree it can be confusing, we can't change that because that would be break change for   `containsOnly` and `containsOnlyElementsOf` that exist for a long time in AssertJ, moreover some people may find that it is normal for the assertion to fail because of the extra expected value.

In that case, you should use the more precise [`isSubsetOf`](http://joel-costigliola.github.io/assertj/core/api/org/assertj/core/api/AbstractIterableAssert.html#isSubsetOf(java.lang.Iterable)) assertion.

Maybe we should mention `isSubsetOf` in the Javadoc `containsOnly` and `containsOnlyElementsOf`, WDYT ?

@joel-costigliola Is this up for grabs? I would like to contribute to this project, because I am using it on a daily basis :) 
Currently searching for issues where I can help.

@btrajkovski good to hear! :)
The only thing to do here is to update the javadoc with a code example showing @afayes example failing as expected and pointing out `isSubsetOf` assertion.

issue.title: Update java docs for containsOnly and containsOnlyElementsOf (#1075)

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Check List:
* Fixes #1075
* Unit tests : YES
* Javadoc with a code example (API only) : YES

body: Thanks for working on this guys!

issue.title: Fixed intermittent failure of tests

repository.name: learn-microservices-w-spring-boot
repository.description: Source code for 'Learn Microservices with Spring Boot' by Moises Macero

issue.body:
containsOnlyElementsOf will fail intermittently when all the numbers
from 11 to 100 are not generated in the loop. For e.g. if number 11 is
not randomly generated in the 1000 times loop then the assertion
containsOnlyElementsOf will fail. The correct assertion is isSubsetOf.

body: Totally agree it's misleading, I expected it to do what isSubsetOf is doing.
@TehBakker would renaming it to `containsAllElementsOf` make it obvious ?
